ReviewList.Text: I got a B+ in Honors Physics, spent about 4 hours a day for a month with this book, got an 800 on the subject test. Occasionally there was a typo, and if I didn't understand a topic, I looked it up on wikipedia. Practice exams were a bit harder than the real one, which helped a lot.

The explanations are not concise and clear. Some topics include contents not closely related to solving questions but rather pieces of knowledge that aren't  needed . Overall hard to understand but practice questions come with explanation and fairly challenging.

I used this book to review for the SAT II Physics, and I can definitely say it helped a lot, because I got a 800. Each chapter had clear and definite concepts and equations that were to be memorized, and the practice tests at the end of each section helped solidify this knowledge. I highly recommend this review book to anyone taking the SAT II or just taking physics in school, because it explains all the basic ideas you should know about every major high school physics topic--from projectiles to magnetism. Committing the equations in this book to memory made me do better on the SAT II and it made me a better overall physics student.

This book was extremely wordy and unclear at times. As others have mentioned, they throw a multitude of equations at the reader that are insufficiently discussed. Basically, the author jumps from point to point with seemingly no logic which forces the reader to just accept everything they say is correct. This left me quite confused at times.

I took the January SAT physics having been through a year of PreAP physics and a semester of Physics B. This book reinforced the knowledge I already had and was able to concisely teach new concepts (much of Electromagnetism).The format is very good. I would highly recommend this book.

This product clearly explains the important concepts that are required to successfully navigate a Physics SAT2 exam. It is clearly written with fine explanations and examples. The book is a must for any student preparing to take the Subject Test in Physics. Alec Q.

As a Barron's review book, I expect it to uphold Barron's reputation. Barron's book's practice tests are all known to be harder than the actual test. However, this book was significantly easier than the real test and thus it did not prepare me for the SAT II physics test

Its a great test prep book, the only problem is that Barron's prep is a lot different from the real Physics SAT. You should buy a College Board book as a supplement. The information Barron's gives is great, but stick with the college board for the practice tests.

I ordered this book and found out that it's not as thick as what I expected. It's only 300+ pages without torque in it at all. I used Barron's math 2 and it works well. So it's a little bit disappointing. Princeton seems to do a better job in this case.

A book for revision, I know, but a few more proofs would have been good. That being said, I found it a very helpful resource for revision, and I highly recommend getting it in preparation for the Physics Subject SAT.

I got a pretty nice score on the Physics Subject Test thanks to this book. I had to teach myself a couple of the concepts and this book helped me greatly. It probably added around 100 points to my score.

I ran out of time to get a paper copy of this book for my son, so the day before the test, I downloaded this version for the Kindle.  He spent the evening studying it and scored an 800 on the test.  It sufficiently covers what you need to know for the test.
